title: Rotational kinematics - disks 1 and 2 relate theta

content.question: Two disks, Disk <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are initially at rest and begin to rotate with a constant angular acceleration. Disk <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has an angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and rotates through an angle <math alttext="theta sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> in a time <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>t</mi></math>. Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has an angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha sub 2 equals 2 alpha sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and rotates through an angle <math alttext="theta sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in the same amount of time <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>t</mi></math>. What is <math alttext="theta sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in terms of <math alttext="theta sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
